column9: I've been taking this medication in different varieties since I was six years old.  I'm 29 now.  I haven't noticed any hair loss.  Keep in mind that you need to take it for 30 days and need to have your blood levels taken again.  Many of the symptoms that people complain about are syptoms for OVER active thyroid, so it could just be an adjustment period or that your dose is too high.  Diarrhea and nausea are symptoms of OVER active as well.  I did have adverse reactions to certain varieties of the med.  For example, synthroid made my face swell up for some reason.  Levothroid irritates my stomach more and Levothroxin seems to be the best for me.  So, that may make a difference.Many people switch to taking it at night, because you need to drink it with water, have to wait 30-60 minutes to eat, and can't drink coffee 60 minutes before or two hours after, because it's a diarretic.  The reason why you can't eat or drink diarretics with this med is because it needs to sit in your stomach for a while to work.  For people with stomach pareeses (nerve damage in the stomach that slows the digestion process) you need to be careful to give it extra time.  However, I find that if I take it at night, I struggle to sleep.  Taking it in the morning, before my shower allows it to kick start my system a little.Iron and some other vitamins can prevent the body from absorbing it properly so be cautious.I'm a 29 year old female, with type 1 diabetes, stomach pareeses, underactive thyroid, excema (from throid issue), chronic anemia.With this medication, my emotions and mental health state are much improved, I am less irritable and moody.  I also have more energy for several hours after taking the med, but it does wear off.  Weight wise, I've never noticed a difference, but without the med, my ankles and lower legs swell.  The thyroid gland sets your metabolism with the thyroid hormone, but it also regulates a lot of things in your body, like breathing and blood circ.
